nodes.text: The Naive Bayes classifier is an effective and reliable method for detecting spam emails on a combined dataset
The study applied a multinomial/text Naive Bayes classifier that assumes conditional independence of words and uses Bayes theorem to compute class posterior probabilities
Data preprocessing consisted of text cleaning (remove punctuation, HTML, stop words, lowercase), tokenization into words, and feature extraction using Bag of Words to produce word-frequency vectors
Likelihoods were estimated by word frequency per class with Laplace smoothing to avoid zero probabilities; classification chooses the class with highest posterior
The dataset combined the 2007 TREC Public Spam Corpus and the Enron-Spam dataset into 83,446 labeled emails and was split 80% train, 20% test preserving class proportions
Model selection used 5-fold cross-validation; fold accuracies were 0.9733, 0.9766, 0.9762, 0.9759, 0.9755 with average 0.9751, and the best model (fold 2) was trained on full training set
On the held-out test subset (16,690 emails), the selected model achieved overall accuracy 97.82%

Class-specific test results: of 7,908 ham emails, 7,800 correctly classified and 108 misclassified as spam (ham accuracy 98.64%); of 8,782 spam emails, 8,526 correctly classified and 256 misclassified as ham (spam accuracy 97.08%)
The combined dataset contained 43,910 spam (52.62%) and 39,538 ham (47.38%); training subset had 66,756 emails (35,128 spam, 31,630 ham) and test subset had 16,690 emails (8,782 spam, 7,908 ham)
Detailed classification metrics on test set: precision ~0.98, recall ~0.98, F1-score ~0.98 for both classes; macro and weighted averages ~0.98
These high and consistent performance metrics across classes indicate the Naive Bayes model can effectively distinguish spam from ham on this dataset

Conclusion and future directions: Naive Bayes is a powerful tool for spam detection in practice; future work could explore hybrid models with SVM or deep learning and incorporate contextual or semantic analysis to improve accuracy
